questions.text: A forensic researcher is conducting a population study on fingerprint patterns to determine which type is most commonly observed in individuals. Among the following fingerprint types, which one is most frequently found?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loop

 

In India as well as in whole world, the incidence of different fingerprints is similar. Loops is the most common followed by whorls, arches and last is composite

 

Core concept 

 

FINGER PRINTING (DACTYLOGRAPHY/ GALTON’S SYSTEM/ DERMATOGLYPHICS)     

 

 

Mnemonic: Love Wife And Children 

 

Other options 

 

Option A) Whorls:This option is incorrect as most common fingerprint pattern is loops.

 

Option C) Composite: This option is incorrect as most common fingerprint pattern is loops.

 

Option D) Arches: This option is incorrect as most common fingerprint pattern is loops.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with the set of symptoms shown in the image, which include a sore and fissured tongue, chapped lips, and angular cheilitis. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Riboflavin

 

Option D:

 

  • This diagnosis is Riboflavin deficiency.
  • Manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis, Circumcorneal vascularization, Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency.
  • INVESTIGATION: Riboflavin status is most commonly assessed by the glutathione reductase activity in freshly lysed red cells

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Deficiency causes beriberi and in chronic alcoholics cause Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome - loss of memory, lackadaisical behaviour, and a continuous rhythmic movement of the eyeballs.

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Deficiency- scurvy, which causes bleeding gums and bone disease.

 

Option C. Vitamin K: Deficiency - bruising tendency, ecchymotic patches, mucous membrane haemorrhage, post-traumatic bleeding, and internal bleeding. NO SKIN MANIFESTATIONS.

 

Educational objective:

 

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency presents with angular cheilitis, chapped lips, and a sore, fissured tongue, known as glossitis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 550 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 480.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy begins experiencing vomiting, night sweats, and tremors after the introduction of fruit juices into his diet during weaning. Physical examination reveals significant hepatomegaly. Urine tests are positive for reducing sugars but negative for glucose. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aldolase B

 

Option C:

 

  • The above symptoms are suggestive of hereditary fructose intolerance (AR inheritance), due to deficiency of aldolase B.
  • Defect in aldolase-B → fructose-1-phosphate cannot be metabolized further → accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase → accumulation of glycogen in liver and associated hypoglycemia.
  • C/F- Vomiting, loss of appetite, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly and jaundice. These symptoms are manifested when sucrose (containing fructose) is introduced in the diet of infants (6 months of age).
  • Diagnosis: Fructose is excreted in urine and urine gives positive Benedict’s test.
  • Treatment: Withdrawal of fructose from the diet will relieve the symptoms.

 

 Explanation:

 

Option A.  Galactokinase: Deficiency in galactokinase leads to galactosemia type 2, which primarily results in cataract formation but does not typically cause severe hypoglycemia or hepatomegaly in response to fructose ingestion.

 

Option B. Fructokinase: Fructokinase deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, a benign condition characterized by the excretion of fructose in the urine without serious metabolic disturbances or clinical symptoms.

 

Option D. β-Galactosidase: Deficiency in β-galactosidase leads to GM1 gangliosidosis or galactosialidosis, which involve neurological symptoms and developmental delays, but not the specific reaction to fructose ingestion as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) is a condition resulting from aldolase B deficiency, characterized by adverse reactions to fructose ingestion, such as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and metabolic disturbances.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 155, 202, 205.

questions.text: The age of eruption of first deciduous molar teeth:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12-14 months

 

Age of eruption of Temporary teeth 

  • Lower central incisors  -  5 to 6 months 
  • Upper central incisors  -  6 to 7 months 
  • Upper lateral incisors  -  7 to 8 months 
  • Lower lateral incisors  -  8 to 9 months 
  • First molars  -  1 year
  • Canines  -  1 ½ years
  • Second molars  -  2 to 2 ½ years

 

Easy way to remember (Rule of halves):

      I (First Incisor) -     06 months

     M (First Molar)-      12 months

     C (Canine)-           18 months

     M (second molar) - 24-30 months 

 

Ref: Medico-legal care for survivors/victims of sexual violence, Government of India, 2013

questions.text: Which of the following method is based on age determination based on weight and height of the erupting teeth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stack’s method 

 

Stack’s method is a technique used for determining the age of infants by evaluating the weight and height of their erupting teeth. This method is specifically designed for infants, as their tooth height and weight correlate closely with their age in months. For example, as an infant ages from one to three months, the height and weight of the teeth increase correspondingly. This relationship is not applicable in older children or adults, where tooth size no longer directly correlates with age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Boyde’s method: This method is based on counting incremental lines in the enamel of teeth. As enamel is deposited daily, these lines can indicate age, especially useful in children and adolescents.

 

Option C. Gustafson Method: This method assesses age in adults, typically over 25 years, based on age-related changes in teeth, such as root transparency, secondary dentin, and attrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect because Stack’s method is indeed related to age determination based on the height and weight of teeth in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stack’s method is used for age determination in infants based on the weight and height of erupting teeth and is not applicable for older children or adults.

questions.text: Small injury causing big size bruise:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Face

 

Small injuries can lead to disproportionately large bruises in areas where the tissues are loose and have a rich blood supply, such as the face. Loose and vascular tissues allow blood to spread more easily, resulting in a larger area of discoloration following minor trauma. This effect is often observed in the face, vulva, and scrotum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scalp: Although the scalp is vascular, its structure does not allow blood to spread as widely as in looser tissue areas like the face.

 

Option C. Palm: The palm has dense, thick tissue and is well-supported, which prevents blood from spreading widely, limiting bruise size.

 

Option D. Sole: Similar to the palm, the sole’s thick tissue and structural support make it resistant to large bruises from minor injuries.

 

Educational Objective:


Small injuries can result in large bruises in areas with loose and vascular tissue, such as the face, vulva, and scrotum, where blood spreads easily due to less supportive tissue structure.

choices.text: 30 cm-1 m

questions.text: The distance between the victim and firearm in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2m-4m

  • The image shows a central rat hole wound with a few satellite wounds.
  • Rat hole wound occurs in gun shot wound after 30 cm
  • Satellite wounds occur after 2m.
  • After 4 m there is only individual pellet wounds and no central wound.
  • Since the image shows central rat hole wound as well as satellite wounds, hence the distance is 2m-4m.

questions.text: Injury shown in the image is a:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laceration

 

  • The above image is of Laceration (caused by blunt force trauma), mimicking an incision.
  • There is presence of “tissue bridging” (arrows) and margins are contusion abraded which helps to differentiate a laceration from an incision.
  • This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”.
  • They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

CORE CONCEPT

 

  • Laceration can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:
  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.
  • “Incised looking lacerated wound” is a special type of lacerated wound which looks like incised wound.
  • It occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.
  • An opposite variety is Lacerated looking incised wound. It is an incised wound, which looks ike lacaerated wound. It occurs in areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc.
  • Here, even an injury produced by sharp weapon appears as if it has irregular margins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Abrasion. It is just the removal of superficial epithelial layer of the skin, whereas in image in question the deeper layers are damaged.

 

Option B) Contusion or bruise. It is the extravasation of blood in the subepithelial tissues due to rupture of blood vessels as a result of blunt force. Skin is intact in bruise, but damaged in the image in question.

 

Option D) Stab wound is produced from penetration with long narrow instruments having pointed ends into the depths of the body, and hence the depth is more than length and width. Whereas, In the image in question, the length is much more than depth.

choices.text: Abnormality of the uterus

questions.text: During a medical conference, a discussion arises about the different causes of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical incompetence

 

Option B:

 

Cervical incompetence, characterized by the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy, is the most common cause of spontaneous abortions in the second trimester. This condition leads to premature dilation and effacement of the cervix, often resulting in mid-pregnancy loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chromosomal defect: More common in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Abnormality of the uterus: Less common than cervical incompetence for second-trimester losses.

 

Option D. Infections: While a potential cause, they are not as common as cervical incompetence in the second trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical incompetence is the primary cause of second-trimester abortion, underscoring the significance of cervical integrity in maintaining pregnancy.

Cervico-uterine (Anatomic) factors usually cause second trimester abortions.

 

  • Cervical incompetence.
  • Congenital malformation of uterus, e.g. hypoplasia, bicornuate/septate uterus or duplication of upper part of uterus.
  • Uterine fibroid

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 400

questions.text: In an experiment, a team of scientists incubates liver cells at 0°C and treats them with trypsin to digest surface receptors. The temperature is then increased to 37°C, and radioactive LDL is introduced to the culture. Subsequently, the labelled LDL is found inside the liver cells. What is the process responsible for the internalization of LDL called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Receptor-mediated endocytosis

 

Option D:

 

  • The LDL is taken up by peripheral tissues in the body by receptor-mediated endocytosis.
  • LDL receptors are located in specialized regions called clathrin coated pits. ​​Binding of LDL to the apo-B100 receptor by apo B100 → the receptor-LDL complex is internalized by endocytosis → endosome vesicle fuses with lysosomes → receptor is recycled and returns to the cell surface and LDL particle + apoproteins + cholesterol ester are hydrolyzed by lysosomal hydrolases → forms fatty acids and free cholesterol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Facilitated diffusion: Is the transport of low-permeability molecules with the aid of a carrier protein.

 

Option B: Pinocytosis: Uptake of small molecules in solution, is receptor –independent.

 

Option C: Phagocytosis: Process by which cells such as macrophages and neutrophils engulf large particles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Receptor-mediated endocytosis is the specific and efficient mechanism by which LDL is internalized by liver cells, involving the interaction of LDL with cell surface LDL receptors.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 257-258.

questions.text: During fasting, the body employs various mechanisms to maintain blood glucose levels. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the order in which these mechanisms are activated to ensure blood glucose homeostasis in the fasting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose from diet > glycogenolysis > gluconeogenesis

 

Option A:

 

In the fasting state, after dietary glucose is depleted, the body first turns to glycogenolysis, the process of breaking down glycogen stored in the liver and muscle tissues into glucose, to maintain blood glucose levels. As fasting continues and glycogen stores become depleted, gluconeogenesis, the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates (such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids), becomes the primary mechanism for maintaining blood glucose levels. This sequence ensures a continuous supply of glucose to vital organs, especially the brain, during periods of fasting.

 

 Explanation:

 

Option B. Glucose from diet > gluconeogenesis > glycogenolysis: This sequence is incorrect because glycogenolysis typically precedes gluconeogenesis in the fasting state as the body utilizes stored glycogen before synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.

 

Option C. Glucose from diet > gluconeogenesis > proteolysis: While proteolysis (the breakdown of proteins) does contribute substrates for gluconeogenesis, it is not a direct mechanism for maintaining blood glucose levels but rather provides amino acids that can be used in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option D. Glucose from diet > lipolysis > gluconeogenesis: Lipolysis, the breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, does provide substrates for gluconeogenesis (specifically glycerol), but it primarily serves as a mechanism for providing energy through fatty acid oxidation rather than directly contributing to maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During starvation:

 

  • Liver produces glucose by glycogenolysis and later by gluconeogenesis so that the obligatory requirements of the brain are met.
  • Liver also produces the ketone bodies, an alternate source of fuel. But the liver cannot use ketone bodies as its own fuel
  • In the fasting state
  • 2-2 1/2 hours – glucose from meals
  • Next 3 hours – from glycogenolysis
  • Later from gluconeogenesis (proteolysis & lipolysis)
  • Hyperglycemic hormones are secreted

 

Liver is the net producer of glucose in the fasting state

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 319-325.

questions.text: In a forensic case involving an allegation of infant abandonment soon after birth, a medical officer is evaluating the mother's medical condition to determine the postpartum period. Understanding the normal postpartum changes, including the phases of lochia discharge, is crucial for timing the events accurately. What is the correct order of the phases of lochia discharge following childbirth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubra, serosa, alba

 

Explanation:

 

The correct order of the phases of lochia discharge following childbirth is rubra, serosa, and alba. 

 

It is a discharge from the uterus which lasts for two or three weeks. It has a peculiar sour, -. During the first 4 to 5 days, the discharge is bright-red and contains large clots (lochia rubra). During the next four days, it becomes serous and paler in colour (lochia serosa). After the ninth day colour becomes yellowish-grey or turbid (lochia alba) until its final disappearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the sequence of lochia discharge phases, which is an important aspect of postpartum care. Lochia rubra is the initial red discharge, followed by lochia serosa (pinkish-brown), and finally, lochia alba (yellowish-white).

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 398

questions.text: A 3-year-old female child is diagnosed with cystic fibrosis after presenting with chronic cough, skin rashes, diarrhea, and foul-smelling stools. Considering her symptoms and the nature of her diagnosis, which vitamin is she most likely deficient in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinol

 

Option A:

 

  • Cystic fibrosis leads to pancreatic damage and decreased secretion of HCO3 − and pancreatic digestive enzymes → fat and protein are absorbed poorly.
  • Retinol is a fat-soluble vitamin which is absorbed along with lipid micelles. The other vitamins listed are water-soluble, their absorption is not significantly affected.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Biotin: Biotin deficiency includes dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations. Injection of biotin 100–300 mg will cure these symptoms.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Its deficiency results in reduced DNA synthesis, Macrocytic Anemia, Hyperhomocysteinemia, Birth Defects and cancer.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Its deficiency manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis, Circumcorneal vascularization and Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis can lead to pancreatic insufficiency and problems with fat malabsorption, including the malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Retinol, or Vitamin A, is a fat-soluble vitamin that is commonly deficient in patients with cystic fibrosis due to its malabsorption. Deficiency can contribute to the skin manifestations and may affect growth and immune function.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 7/e: 382-385,464-469.

questions.text: A 19-year-old African female presents with chronic, mild symptoms of sleeping sickness, persisting over two years. She is treated with difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO), known for its efficacy against trypanosomiasis. DFMO inhibits the enzyme involved in polyamine synthesis, crucial for the parasite's proliferation. Based on DFMO's mechanism, what type of enzyme inhibition does it exemplify?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Suicidal Inhibition

 

Option A.

 

  • It is also known as mechanism-based inactivation. 
  • Here the inhibitor makes use of the enzyme’s own reaction mechanism to inactivate it.
  • In suicide inhibition, the structural analog is converted to a more effective inhibitor with the help of the enzyme to be inhibited.
  • For example, ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) catalyzes the conversion of ornithine to putrescine which is important for polyamine synthesis. Thus, when the ODC in trypanosoma is inhibited → multiplication of the parasite is arrested. Therefore, inhibitors of ODC enzyme such as difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO) are found to be effective against trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).
  • A similar mechanism is noted in the case of Allopurinol which is oxidized by xanthine oxidase to alloxanthine which is a strong inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • The anti-inflammatory action of Aspirin is based on the suicide inhibition. Arachidonic acid is converted to prostaglandin by the enzyme Cyclo-oxygenase.  Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in the active centre of cyclo-oxygenase, thus prostaglandin synthesis is inhibited and so inflammation subsides.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, Fluoride inhibit enolase thereby consequently the glycolysis, Iodoacetate inhibit enzymes having –SH group in their active centers, BAL (dimercaprol) as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning etc.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive: Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan iso-enzyme) by phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Allosteric: ALA Synthase catalyse the first step in heme biosynthesis and the end product, heme will allosterically inhibit the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DFMO acts as a suicidal (or suicide) inhibitor by irreversibly binding to and inactivating ornithine decarboxylase, the enzyme responsible for polyamine synthesis essential for the growth and reproduction of Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite causing sleeping sickness. Suicidal inhibitors form a covalent bond with the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p78.

choices.text: Ubiquitin is the most important chaperones

questions.text: A graduate student is preparing a presentation on protein folding and the role of molecular chaperones in maintaining cellular protein homeostasis. While researching, the student encounters various facts about chaperones but realizes one of the statements they've noted is incorrect. Which of the following statements about chaperones is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ubiquitin is the most important chaperones

 

Option C:

 

Ubiquitin is not a chaperone but a small regulatory protein that is involved in ubiquitination, a process that tags proteins for degradation by the proteasome. Chaperones, on the other hand, assist in the correct folding of proteins and the prevention of misfolded protein aggregation.

 

Note - Ubiquitin is the key molecule of protein degradation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Many chaperones do belong to the family of heat shock proteins (HSPs), which are upregulated in response to stress to protect cells by preventing protein aggregation and assisting in protein refolding.

 

Option B: Chaperones are ubiquitous and are found in organisms ranging from bacteria to humans, playing essential roles in protein folding and maintenance.

 

Option D: Chaperones are often referred to as stress proteins due to their upregulation in response to cellular stress and their role in protecting cells by stabilizing proteins and complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some Properties of Chaperone Proteins:

 

  • Present in a wide range of species from bacteria to humans
  • Many are heat shock proteins (Hsp) and are known as stress proteins.
  • Some are inducible by conditions which cause unfolding of newly synthesized proteins (e.g. elevated temperature and various chemicals).
  • They bind to predominantly hydrophobic regions of unfolded proteins thus preventing their aggregation.
  • They act as a quality control or editing mechanism for detecting misfolded or defective proteins.
  • Most chaperones have associated ATPase activity, with ATP or ADP being involved in the protein-chaperone interaction.
  • Found in various cellular compartments such as cytosol, mitochondria, and the lumen of the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 609.

choices.text: Injuries sustained are non-accidental
Undue delay in seeking medical advice
The history is consistent with the injuries
Injuries are of different duration

questions.text: In a lecture on child abuse, the professor discusses Caffey's Syndrome, a condition often associated with non-accidental injuries in children. The students are asked to identify which feature is not true regarding Caffey's Syndrome. Which of the following statements about Caffey's Syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The history is consistent with the injuries.

 

Option C:

 

In cases of Caffey's Syndrome, which is often associated with child abuse, the history provided by caregivers often does not correlate with the injuries observed, making option C incorrect.

 

Battered Baby Syndrome: It is also known as child abuse syndrome, Caffey’s syndrome or non-accidental injury of childhood. The classical features are:

 

  1. Discrepancy between the nature of injuries and the explanation offered by the parents.
  2. Delay between injury and medical attention cannot be explained by caregiver.
  3. Injuries of different age groups
  4. Victims are usually male of less than 3 years old and belong to low social class and education.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Injuries sustained are non-accidental: True, as Caffey's Syndrome is often linked to child abuse.

 

Option B. Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True, and this delay in seeking treatment is a common feature in child abuse cases.

 

Option D. Injuries are of different duration: True, indicating repeated abuse over time, with injuries in various stages of healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian. In addition to physical injury, there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection. The key identifier is the inconsistency between the history provided and the injuries observed, which is a hallmark of non-accidental injury in child abuse cases.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

questions.text: If a victims’ gunshot entry and exit wound are not properly distinguishable during post-mortem due to corrective surgery, it is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kennedy phenomenon

 

The Kennedy phenomenon refers to a situation during post-mortem examination where distinguishing between entry and exit wounds in a gunshot injury becomes difficult due to prior surgical intervention. Corrective surgeries, such as incisions, suturing, or the insertion of medical devices, can alter or obscure the original wound characteristics. This phenomenon is named after President John F. Kennedy, whose gunshot wounds were reportedly challenging to analyze post-mortem due to surgical alterations made in attempts to save his life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. McNaughton phenomenon: This is unrelated to forensic examination and is associated with legal defenses based on insanity.

 

Option C. Ricochet phenomenon: Refers to the deviation of a bullet’s trajectory after it hits an object, unrelated to post-mortem wound analysis.

 

Option D. Alec Jeffrey phenomenon: Associated with DNA fingerprinting innovations and not related to wound analysis.

 

Educational Objective:


The Kennedy phenomenon describes the challenge of identifying gunshot entry and exit wounds in post-mortem examinations due to surgical alterations, named after the case of President John F. Kennedy.

questions.text: Number of teeth at 7 years:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 24 


At 7 years old, a child typically has a total of 24 teeth. This includes a combination of primary (baby) teeth and some permanent teeth, as children begin transitioning from primary to permanent teeth around age 6. The general rule to estimate the number of permanent teeth during this period is given by the formula: (age - 5) × 4. For a 7-year-old, this calculation suggests 8 permanent teeth, with the rest still being primary teeth, totaling to 24.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 20: By age 7, children typically have more than 20 teeth as they are well into the transition from primary to permanent teeth.

 

Option C. 26: While close, 26 teeth are more likely by a slightly older age as the transition continues with additional permanent teeth erupting.

 

Option D. 28: 28 teeth are typically not reached until later in childhood as more permanent teeth come in.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand that at 7 years, a child usually has around 24 teeth, including a mix of primary and permanent teeth, with the number of permanent teeth roughly estimated by the formula (age - 5) × 4.

questions.text: Which group among the following is responsible for buffering activity of proteins at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Imidazole group

 

Option D:

 

The imidazole group, which is part of the histidine amino acid side chain, has significant buffering capacity at physiological pH (around 7.4). This is because the pKa of the imidazole group is close to the physiological pH, allowing it to effectively donate or accept protons, thereby contributing to buffering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Sulfhydryl group - Present in cysteine, important for forming disulfide bonds, but not primarily known for buffering.

 

Option B: Indole group - Found in tryptophan, contributes to the protein's structural and functional aspects but lacks significant buffering capacity.

 

Option C: Phenyl group - Part of phenylalanine, contributes to hydrophobic interactions in proteins but does not have a buffering role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Only amino acid whose pKa value (6.1) is nearby physiological pH (7.4) is Histidine (Imidazole group), due to which it has buffering activity at physiological pH.

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 28.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic renal failure is admitted to the ICU. His prolonged hospitalization has led to malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies. Which of the following is used for the functional assessment of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RBC transketolase         

 

Option C:

 

  • Thiamine nutritional status can be assessed by erythrocyte transketolase activation.
  • The activation of apo-transketolase (the enzyme protein) in erythrocyte lysate by thiamin diphosphate added in vitro has become the accepted index of thiamin nutritional status.
  • In thiamine deficiency, blood levels of thiamine are reduced with increase in pyruvate, alpha ketoglutarate, and lactate.
  • Also Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced which is the earliest manifestation before the clinical manifestations sets in.
  • Erythrocyte transketolase levels are also reduced in other conditions like comatose patients, alcoholics, chronic renal failure, malnutrition, patients in ICU as well as in elderly patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum thiamine levels: In thiamine deficiency, though the blood thiamine levels are reduced, reduction in erythrocyte transketolase activity is the earliest manifestation seen before the appearance of clinical manifestations.

 

Option B. RBC glutathione peroxidase and Option D. RBC glutathione reductase: Glutathione is present in RBCs, used for inactivation of free radicals that is formed inside RBC with the help of a selenium containing enzyme glutathione peroxidase (GPx) and the glutathione is regenerated by glutathione reductase (GR), an NADPH dependent enzyme. (NADPH is derived from GPD shunt pathway and its deficiency attributes to hemolysis and impairment of regeneration of reduced glutathione)

 

Educational objective:

 

The functional assessment of Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency is typically done using the RBC transketolase activity assay. An increase in the enzyme's activity upon the addition of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) indicates a deficiency in thiamine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 556 , Lippincott 7/e : P 379

choices.text: Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from C-terminal end
α 2-Macroglobulin is the major serine protease inhibitor of plasma
Chymotrypsin acts on peptide bonds in which the amino acid C-terminal to the bond is a tryptophan, tyrosine, phenylalanine.
Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site

questions.text: In a discussion on the biochemical properties of serine proteases, a molecular biologist outlines several characteristics common to this class of enzymes. Serine proteases play critical roles in various physiological processes, including digestion and coagulation. Which of the following features is universally found in all serine proteases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Presence of Ser-His-Asp catalytic triad at the active site. 

 

Option D.

 

  • Serine Proteases are proteolytic enzymes with Serine at their active Site
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of Serine Proteases: Ser, His, Asp.
  • Eg: Chymotrypsin, Trypsin, Elastase, Thrombin, Plasmin, Complements and Factor X and XI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trypsin is activated by the removal of a hexapeptide from N-terminal end.

 

Option B.α 1-Antitrypsin is the major serine protease inhibitor of plasma. Genetic deficiency of this protein results in emphysema and liver disease.

 

Option C. Chymotrypsin acts on peptide bonds formed in which the amino acid N-terminal to the bond is a tryptophan, tyrosine, phenylalanine

 

Educational Objective:

 

All serine proteases share a common catalytic mechanism that involves a conserved Ser-His-Asp triad at their active sites. This triad plays a crucial role in the catalytic activity of these enzymes, with the serine residue acting as a nucleophile in the cleavage of peptide bonds.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 62, 63.

questions.text: The image below indicates?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Typical hanging

 

The image demonstrates typical hanging, which is characterized by a ligature mark forming a well-defined, oblique, and V-shaped pattern, with the knot commonly located at the nape of the neck (occipital region). This positioning of the knot ensures that the ligature mark aligns with gravitational forces, creating the characteristic pattern seen in typical hangings. The body is usually suspended fully or partially, depending on the circumstances.

 

In this image, the ligature's placement and the classic V-shaped pattern indicate a typical hanging scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atypical Hanging: This is incorrect because atypical hanging involves an unusual placement of the knot, such as on the side or front of the neck, resulting in a non-standard ligature mark. The image shows a typical pattern consistent with typical hanging.

 

Option C. Partial Hanging: Partial hanging occurs when the body is not completely suspended and some part of it remains in contact with the ground or another surface. The ligature mark shown in the image does not specifically indicate partial hanging and is more consistent with a typical hanging.

 

Option D. Complete Hanging: Complete hanging involves the full suspension of the body without any contact with the ground. While complete hanging may result in a similar ligature mark, the key feature in the question is the ligature's pattern, which defines this as typical hanging rather than specifying the degree of suspension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typical hanging is identified by a V-shaped, oblique ligature mark caused by the knot's position at the nape of the neck, consistent with gravitational forces.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly, with abnormal liver function tests suggesting ethanol toxicity. What could be the underlying biochemical change associated with ethanol toxicity in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio 

 

Option B:

      

Ethanol metabolism in the liver primarily involves alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde dehydrogenase, converting ethanol first to acetaldehyde and then to acetate, a process accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. This shift towards an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio has several metabolic consequences, including inhibition of gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation, and stimulation of lactate production (leading to an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio) and lipogenesis. The accumulation of NADH promotes the conversion of pyruvate to lactate and oxaloacetate to malate, contributing to lactic acidosis and malate accumulation, respectively. Furthermore, the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio disrupts the TCA cycle and encourages the synthesis of fatty acids, leading to fatty liver (steatosis), a common feature in chronic alcohol consumption.

 

 Explanation:

 

Option A. Decreased lactate/pyruvate ratio: Ethanol metabolism actually leads to an increased lactate/pyruvate ratio due to the conversion of pyruvate to lactate in the presence of excess NADH.

 

Option C. Stimulation of gluconeogenesis: Ethanol metabolism inhibits gluconeogenesis due to the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and the subsequent diversion of substrates like pyruvate and oxaloacetate to lactate and malate, respectively.

 

Option D. Stimulation of fatty acid oxidation: Ethanol metabolism inhibits fatty acid oxidation, again due to the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. Instead, there is an accumulation of fatty acids leading to fatty liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both the oxidation steps in alcohol metabolism produce NADH, resulting in a high NADH/NAD+ ratio. As a result, the following metabolic adaptations occur:

 

  1. Lactic acidosis.
  2. Hypoglycemia.
  3. Ketogenesis.
  4. Fatty liver and steatosis.
  5. Mitochondrial damage and apoptosis.
  6. CNS depression

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e:317, DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 140-141

questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 17-18 years

 

  • Head, greater trochanter, and lesser trochanter are all fused with the shaft of femur (so age > 17 years)
  • Iliac crest is not yet fused (so age < 18 years)
  • Hence, age is 17-18 years.

 

Core Concept

 

Femur

Head – 1 yr (A)                         

Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)

Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)              fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis

 

 

 

Other Options are self explanatory from the explanation above

choices.text: Both B and C

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a community health center with a newborn, claiming to have delivered the child at home with the help of a local midwife. She requests a birth certificate and insists on documenting the child as the heir to her recently divorced husband, alleging the conception occurred prior to their separation. What term best describes the act of presenting a living child, not one's own, as if born to oneself, particularly to claim inheritance rights?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suppositious Child

 

Option C:

 

The fraud child presented for the purpose of financial gain is typically called suppositious child. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine. It is a fraudulent offspring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posthumous Child: It is a child born after the death of its father; the mother being conceived by the said father.

 

Option B. Fictional Child: A "fictitious child" generally refers to a child who does not exist and is purely a creation of imagination or fiction. Fictitious children are often found in literature, storytelling etc. So, while a suppositious child is a fraud, but do exist in reality, whereas fictional children do not exist at all.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A "suppositious child" is fraudulently presented as one's own for financial gain, unlike a "posthumous child," born after the father's death, or a "fictional child," which is purely imaginary.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 397

questions.text: Bumper fracture is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary impact injury 

 

A bumper fracture is classified as a primary impact injury and typically occurs when the bumper of a vehicle initially strikes a pedestrian's leg. This impact often results in a fracture of the tibia or fibula (lower leg bones). The primary impact injury occurs at the first point of contact between the vehicle and the pedestrian. Secondary and tertiary impact injuries refer to additional injuries sustained after the initial impact, such as when the pedestrian strikes another surface (e.g., the ground) or other parts of the vehicle. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary impact injury: Secondary impact injuries refer to injuries that occur after the initial point of impact, often from further contact with parts of the vehicle or the ground.

 

Option C. Tertiary impact injury: Tertiary impact injuries involve the body striking a surface other than the vehicle (e.g., the ground) after being thrown from the force of the impact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bumper fracture is considered a primary impact injury, occurring at the first contact point between a vehicle’s bumper and the pedestrian’s leg, often resulting in a fracture of the tibia or fibula.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child's remains are discovered in a secluded area, and a forensic team is tasked with the investigation. Given the state of decomposition, the team faces challenges in establishing the child's exact age at the time of death, which is crucial for the ongoing investigation. The forensic expert, aware of the importance of skeletal development in age estimation for children, decides to focus on specific joints for examination. In the context of a child between 2 to 6 years old, which joint would the forensic expert prioritize to provide the most accurate age estimation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wrist joint

 

  • Ossification of the carpal bones occurs in a predictable sequence, starting with the capitate and ending with the pisiform.
  • At birth, there is no calcification in the carpal bones.
  • Capitate and hamate ossifies during infancy (1 year), the former preceding the later.
  • Between 2-6 years, the number of carpal bones present on X-ray wrist represents the approximate age in years, e.g. 3 carpal bones – 3 years.
  • Approximate ossification times are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shoulder joint: At 5–6 years, the three (Head, Greater tubercle and Lesser tubercle) fuses together (conjoint epiphysis) and at 17–18 years, fuses with the shaft.

 

Option C. Elbow joint: Humerus at 14–15 years, Capitulum, Trochlea and Lateral epicondyle fuses with the shaft; & at 16 years medial epicondyle fuses with the shaft. Radius and Ulna upper end fuses at 15-17 years.

 

Option D. Ankle joint: Tibia and Fibula Lower end fuses at 16-17 years; Talus and Calcaneum fuses at 17-18 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wrist joint as the key anatomical site for the estimation of age in children between 2 to 6 years old, utilizing the appearance and fusion of multiple ossification centers.

 

NOTE: X-rays of elbow, wrist, clavicle and shoulder joints (upper extremity) and hip, knee and ankle joints (lower extremity) are usually recommended to determine the age before 25 years of age. If all the epiphyses of all the long bones are united, the person is most probably over 25 years of age.

questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intermediate range

  • In the image, around the firearm wound, only Tattooing is present.
  • There is no blackening or singeing.
  • This is characteristic of intermediate range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Close Range. Burning, blackening and tattooing are present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent), but in the question only tattooing is present.

 

Option C. Point Blank. It refers to extremely close range, but not in contact. So, the features are similar to close range.

 

Option D. Distant Range. Neither of three features (singeing, blackening and tattooing) are present in distant range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ENTRY WOUND FEATURES

  • Contact (tight contact): Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • Close Contact (Close Range contact/Point Blank/Loose contact/Near contact#): Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • Intermediate Range/Near range#/Medium Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range/Long Range: None of these present around the wound.

 

#Near Contact and Near range are different.

questions.text: Garrod's tetrad refers to a group of four metabolic disorders. Which of the following options correctly lists these disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Alkaptonuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, Albinism

 

Option A:

 

Garrod's tetrad includes four inborn errors of metabolism that were initially described by Archibald Garrod. These are Alkaptonuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, and Albinism. Garrod is known for his pioneering work in the field of genetics and metabolism, and these disorders were among the first to be understood in the context of genetic inheritance and metabolic dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Alkaptonuria, Pentos Uria, Galactosemia, Albinism: While galactosemia is a well-known metabolic disorder, it is not part of Garrod's original tetrad.

 

Option C. Fructosuria, Pentosuria, Cystinuria, Albinism: Fructosuria is another metabolic condition but was not included in Garrod's tetrad.

 

Option D. Alkaptonuria, Pentos Uria, Cystinuria, Mucopolysaccharidosis: Mucopolysaccharidosis refers to a group of lysosomal storage diseases and is not part of Garrod's tetrad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Garrod’s tetrad includes

Cystinuria
Alkaptonuria
Albinism
Pentosuria

(Mnemonic- CAAP)

questions.text: During a forensic examination, a pathologist investigates a deceased individual with distinct marks on the body. The victim presents with petechial hemorrhages in the eyes, cyanosis of the nails, and bruising in the shape of a hand around the neck. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Throttling

 

  •  
  • The correct answer is option C, Throttling, as the described findings are indicative of death by manual strangulation, which is usually associated with homicide.
  • Throttling is manual strangulation and is characterized by bruising that may resemble the shape of a hand, along with other signs of asphyxia such as petechial hemorrhages and cyanosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Hanging typically causes a ligature mark around the neck, not the bruising in the shape of a hand.

 

Option B) Poisoning can cause cyanosis but is less likely to cause the physical marks consistent with manual strangulation.

 

Option D) Drowning is associated with signs of asphyxia but would not typically result in the bruising pattern seen with throttling.

choices.text: It prevents lipolysis by inhibiting the activity of hormone sensitive lipase
It increases proteins synthesis and prevents protein breakdown

questions.text: Regarding the metabolic effects of insulin, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It stimulates glycogenolysis

 

Option B:

 

Insulin is an anabolic hormone that promotes the storage of glucose, fatty acids, and amino acids in cells. Its actions are primarily directed towards lowering blood glucose levels and preventing the breakdown of stored energy. Specifically, insulin inhibits glycogenolysis, which is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose, not stimulates it. This is in line with insulin's overall role in reducing blood glucose levels by encouraging the storage of glucose in the form of glycogen in liver and muscle cells.

 

other options:

 

Option A. It prevents lipolysis by inhibiting the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase: This statement is true. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue, thereby reducing the breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, which is known as lipolysis.

 

Option C. It increases protein synthesis and prevents protein breakdown: This is accurate. Insulin promotes the uptake of amino acids by cells and stimulates protein synthesis while inhibiting protein degradation, thus supporting anabolic processes.

 

Option D. It decreases gluconeogenesis in cells: This statement is correct. Insulin inhibits gluconeogenesis, which is the generation of glucose from non-carbohydrate substrates, further contributing to the reduction of blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Glucose Uptake
  • Insulin facilitates diffusion of glucose in muscle.
  • Transporter, GLUT-4 is insulin dependent
  1. Utilization of Glucose: Glycolysis increased (key glycolytic enzymes: glucokinase, phosphofructokinase & pyruvate kinase)
  2. Insulin favors storage of glucose: Glycogen synthesis increased (Glycogen synthase) (option B)
  3. Lipogenesis increased: Acetyl CoA Carboxylase and Glucose-6-Phosphate   dehydrogenase (NADPH) activity is enhanced by insulin.
  4. Anti-lipolytic effect: Hormone sensitive lipase is decreased (option A).
  5. Gluconeogenesis Decreased (Key gluconeogenic enzymes: Pyruvate carboxylase, Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase, Fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase and Glucose 6-phosphatase are inhibited by insulin. (option D)
  6. Anti-ketogenic Effect: HMG CoA synthase is decreased
  7. It increases proteins synthesis and prevents protein breakdown

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p319-322.

choices.text: Increasing the synthesis and secretion of VLDL from liver resulting in high LDL levels in the blood
Inhibiting the binding of apoB to LDL receptor, thereby blocking the lipoprotein uptake and increasing the blood cholesterol levels
Decreasing the availability of LDL receptors on the cell surface, resulting in decreased LDL uptake and high blood cholesterol level
Preventing the cholesterol breakdown into bile acids in the liver

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with coronary artery disease (CAD) is being successfully treated with anti-atherogenic medication that targets PCSK9. Following treatment, his lipid profile normalizes, and his cardiac status improves. What is the primary function of PCSK9?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing the availability of LDL receptors on the cell surface, resulting in decreased LDL uptake and high blood cholesterol level

 

PCSK9 (Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9) normally binds to LDL receptors and promotes their degradation in lysosomes, which prevents the receptors from being recycled back to the cell surface. This natural function of PCSK9 decreases the number of LDL receptors available on cell surfaces, especially hepatocytes, resulting in reduced LDL clearance from the bloodstream and consequently higher blood cholesterol levels.

 

Anti-atherogenic medications that target PCSK9 (PCSK9 inhibitors) work by inhibiting this protein, thereby preventing LDL receptor degradation. This leads to:

  • Increased recycling of LDL receptors back to the cell surface
  • Greater availability of LDL receptors on hepatocytes
  • Enhanced clearance of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream
  • Reduced blood LDL cholesterol levels
  • Improved cardiovascular outcomes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Increasing the synthesis and secretion of VLDL - PCSK9 does not directly affect VLDL synthesis or secretion; its primary role is related to LDL receptor regulation.

 

Option B: Inhibiting the binding of apoB to the LDL receptor - PCSK9 does not interfere with apoB binding to LDL receptors; it affects the degradation of LDL receptors themselves.

 

Option D: Preventing the breakdown of cholesterol into bile acids - PCSK9's function is not related to cholesterol metabolism into bile acids; it specifically impacts the recycling and degradation of LDL receptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that PCSK9 inhibitors work by preventing PCSK9-mediated degradation of LDL receptors, thereby increasing LDL receptor availability, enhancing LDL cholesterol clearance, and lowering blood cholesterol levels in patients with coronary artery disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 271, 275, 278-279.

questions.text: All are components of gun-powder EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lead peroxide

 

Black gun powder: Contains Potassium nitrate 75% + Charcoal 15% + sulphur 10%

 

Smokeless Powder is of following types:

 

Single Base: Contains nitrocellulose,

 

Double Base: contains nitrocellulose + nitroglycerine

 

Triple Base: Contains Nitrocellulose + Nitroglycerine + nitroguanidine

 

Primers: lead peroxide + lead styphnate + tetrazene + barium nitrate

 

 

 Ref:  Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 239

choices.text: Ligature Strangulation

questions.text: A man is killed by his brother over a property dispute. In post-mortem examination, a finding similar to the one shown in this radiological picture is seen. What could be the most possible cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling

  • The picture in question shows inward fracture of Hyoid bone. This is most commonly seen in throttling.
  • Neck injuries in asphyxial deaths:
    • Neck injuries indicate compression of neck.
    • Common causes of compression of neck are manual strangulation (MS), ligature strangulation (LS) and Hanging (H).
    • Incidence of most neck injuries (e.g. Thyroid fracture, muscle injuries, larynx fracture etc.) are MS > LS > H.
    • Exceptions:
      • Incidence of Hyoid fracture, Carotid artery tear: MS> H > LS
      • Incidence of Cervical Vertebrae fracture (C2-C3): Only Judicial hanging
         
    • Hyoid fracture: 
      • Overall incidence of Hyoid fracture: most common in MS
      • Internal fracture of Hyoid: Most common in MS
      • Outward fracture of Hyoid: Most common in H 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burking: It does not cause hyoid fracture or any other neck injury, as it is the compression of chest and closure of mouth and nose.

 

Option C. Ligature Strangulation: Hyoid fracture in LS is rare. It is much more common in MS.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hyoid # in hanging is outward # as shown below.

questions.text: Tailing of the Incised wound helps to know?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direction of the wound

 

Tailing refers to the characteristic of an incised wound where it is deeper at the starting point and gradually becomes shallower towards the end. This pattern occurs because the force applied is typically stronger at the beginning of the incision and decreases as the weapon is drawn away. The presence of tailing in an incised wound helps forensic experts determine the direction in which the weapon was moved.

 

For example, if an incision starts deep and becomes shallow towards a particular point, it indicates the direction of the wound from the deeper to the shallower end.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of the wound: Tailing does not provide information about how long ago the wound was inflicted.

 

Option C. Shape of the weapon: Tailing does not directly reveal the shape of the weapon used; it only indicates the direction of the force.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect, as tailing does indeed help in determining the direction of the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tailing in an incised wound is an indication of the direction of the wound, with the deeper end representing the starting point and the shallower end indicating the finishing point.

questions.text: During a discussion about the metabolism of vitamin D, a physician explains the process of activation to a group of medical residents. The physician asks the residents to identify where 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is hydroxylated by the 1 α-hydroxylase enzyme to form the active form of vitamin D. In which organ does this conversion predominantly occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kidney

 

Option C:

 

  • In the kidney, 25-HCC is hydroxylated at the 1st position by 1-alpha hydroxylase which is located in the mitochondria of PCT.
  • It requires cytochrome P-450, NADPH and ferredoxin.
  • Hence 1, 25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol (DHCC)/ Calcitriol is generated.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skin: Here, most of the precursor for 1,25(OH)2-D3 synthesis is produced in the Malpighian layer of the epidermis from 7-dehydrocholesterol through UV light-mediated, nonenzymatic photolysis reaction.

 

Option B. Liver: 25-Hydroxylation takes place here.

 

Option D. Heart: No role.

 

Educational objective:

 

25-hydroxycholecalciferol, also known as calcifediol, is hydroxylated by the 1 α-hydroxylase enzyme primarily in the kidneys to form 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), which is the active form of vitamin D. This hydroxylation is crucial for the regulation of calcium homeostasis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 508 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 470

questions.text: Which organelle is primarily responsible for sorting proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golgi bodies

 

Option A:

 

Golgi bodies, also known as the Golgi apparatus, are responsible for the sorting, packaging, and modification of proteins that have been synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum. They play a key role in preparing proteins for their specific destinations, either within or outside the cell.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mitochondria: Electron transport chain, ATP generation, TCA cycle, beta oxidation of fatty acids, ketone body production, urea synthesis (part), heme synthesis (part), gluconeogenesis (part), pyrimidine synthesis (part).

 

Option C: Ribosomes: Biosynthesis of proteins.

 

Option D: Lysosomes: Degradation of proteins, carbohydrates, lipids and nucleotides

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functions of Golgi bodies:

 

  1. O-Glycosylation of proteins
  2. Protein sorting
  3. Processing of oligosaccharide chains of Glycoproteins

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 608.

choices.text: Due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase
Mental retardation is a potential complication
Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan
Phenylacetate is found in the urine

questions.text: During a routine neonatal examination, a newborn girl is noted to have blue eyes, blond hair, and fair skin. A Guthrie test is performed, yielding positive results. Among the following statements related to this case, which one is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan

 

Option C:

 

This case describes a newborn with classic physical features of phenylketonuria (PKU) - blue eyes, blond hair, and fair skin - who has tested positive on the Guthrie test, a screening test for elevated phenylalanine levels.

 

Statement C is incorrect because the hypopigmentation (lighter hair and skin) seen in PKU is not related to tryptophan deficiency. Rather, it results from Reduced tyrosine availability (since phenylalanine cannot be converted to tyrosine)

Tryptophan is an essential amino acid involved in serotonin synthesis, but it does not play a direct role in the pigmentation pathways affected in PKU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: This statement is true. PKU is caused by mutations in the gene encoding phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), which normally converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Without functional PAH, phenylalanine accumulates to toxic levels in the body.

 

Option B. Mental retardation is a potential complication: This statement is true. Untreated PKU can lead to significant intellectual disability due to the neurotoxic effects of elevated phenylalanine and its metabolites. Early diagnosis and dietary management can prevent this outcome.

 

Option D. Phenylacetate is found in the urine: This statement is true. In PKU, the excess phenylalanine is metabolized through alternative pathways, producing phenylketones including phenylpyruvate, phenyllactate, and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine. The presence of these compounds gives PKU its name and produces the characteristic "musty" or "mousy" odor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phenylketonuria results from phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, causing elevated phenylalanine levels and reduced tyrosine. The hypopigmentation seen in PKU patients is due to impaired melanin synthesis from reduced tyrosine availability—not from tryptophan deficiency. Early detection through newborn screening and prompt dietary management are essential to prevent the neurological sequelae of this inborn error of metabolism.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 304-306

questions.text: Avulsion is a type of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) laceration 

 

Avulsion is classified as a type of laceration. Lacerations are injuries caused by blunt force trauma that tears the skin and underlying tissue. In an avulsion laceration, also known as an "evulsion," a portion of the skin and potentially some of the underlying tissue is forcibly detached from the body. This type of laceration often occurs in high-impact injuries, such as road traffic accidents, where rotational or shearing forces can tear skin and tissue away. Avulsion lacerations are unique because a large portion of the tissue may remain attached, albeit partially.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chop wound: This type of wound is caused by a heavy, sharp object like an axe. Chop wounds exhibit features of both sharp and blunt force trauma, including clean cuts with contusions and bruising at the margins. This does not align with the mechanism seen in avulsion lacerations.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Incised wounds are caused by sharp instruments, resulting in clean, straight edges without tissue bridging. Avulsions, however, result from blunt trauma and usually show irregular and torn margins with tissue bridges.

 

Additional Information on Types of Lacerations

 

  1. Split Laceration – Occurs over bony prominences, such as the scalp, forehead, or iliac crest. In split lacerations, the wound edges may appear sharp, similar to an incised wound, and are often called "incised-looking lacerations."
  2. Stretch Laceration – Caused by over-stretching of the skin, often seen when force is applied, such as a kick with a shoe, creating tears in the skin.
  3. Avulsion Laceration – Characterized by tissue detachment due to forces like grinding or rotational impacts, often seen in road traffic accidents.
  4. Tear or Tension Laceration – Results from localized impact with irregular objects (e.g., a stone), causing a tearing effect on the skin.

 

Note:

 

Cut Laceration or Chop Wound – Results from heavy, relatively sharp instruments (e.g., axe or large blade), leaving a wound with features of both blunt and sharp force trauma, including deep cuts with bruised and abraded margins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avulsion is a type of laceration resulting from blunt trauma that causes a portion of skin and underlying tissue to be partially or completely torn away, often seen in cases involving rotational or shearing forces, such as in road traffic accidents.

questions.text: Is the statement "Calreticulin is considered a chaperone protein" correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True

 

Option A:

 

Calreticulin is a chaperone protein. It is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of cells and has several functions, including ensuring proper folding of newly synthesized proteins and maintaining calcium homeostasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molecular Chaperones are

 

  • HSP 70
  • HSP 90
  • HSP 40 [Cochaperone]
  • BiP [Immunoglobulin heavy chain binding protein]
  • Glucose Regulated Protein [GRP-94]
  • Calreticulin
  • Calnexin.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 608-610.

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a workshop on various tests used to determine live birth in cases of infant death. These tests are essential to distinguish between infants who were born alive and those who were stillborn. Which of the following tests is not used to detect live birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Winslow test

 

Option D:

 

Winslow’s test: No movement of reflection of light shown on mirror or surface of water in bowl kept on the chest. Now obsolete. The Winslow test is not specifically used to detect live birth.

 

Other Tests to detect stoppage of respiration (obsolete)

 

  • Feather test: No movement is seen, if a feather or fine cotton fibers are held before the nostrils.
  • Mirror test: No haziness is seen on the reflecting surface of the mirror held in front of mouth and nostrils.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fodere's test is used to demonstrate lung floatation, indicative of breathing and thus live birth. The lungs are ligated across their hila and separated. The average weight of both lungs before respiration varies from 30 to 40 g., and after respiration from 60 to 66 g. The increase in weight is due to the increased flow of blood.

 

Option B. Ploucquet's test is another lung floatation test used to determine if an infant had breathed. The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to the said ratio before respiration (1/70 of body weight).

 

Option C. Wredin's test - Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air. With respiration, the sphincter at the pharyngeal end of eustachian tube relaxes and air replaces the gelatinous substances in few hours to five weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding different forensic tests used to detect live birth and distinguishing them from tests that serve other purposes.

 

  • Winslow test = test to determine stoppage of respiration
  • Fodere's test = weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g
  • Plocquet's test = ratio of weight of lungs to weight of body; before respiration = 1:70 and after respiration = 1:35
  • Wredin's test = before respiration gelatinous tissue in middle ear & after respiration, air in middle ear

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152, 439

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a constellation of symptoms including flushing, a non-healing ulcer, diarrhea, and episodes of bronchospasm. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA) in her blood. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoid syndrome  

 

Option C:

                                        

  • Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin resulting from tumours of argentaffin cells in GIT.
  • C/F: flushing, sweating, intermittent diarrhoea and fluctuating hypertension.
  • 5-HIAA is the catabolic end product of serotonin. So its level is increased in this disorder 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A Glucagonoma: Is a rare tumour of pancreatic alpha cells, resulting in overproduction of glucagon. It is associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss and diabetes mellitus.

 

 Option B. Gastrinoma: Is a gastrin secreting tumour of pancreas resulting in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, where there is no feedback regulation of gastrin secretion causing very high level of gastric acid output along with high serum gastrin levels.

 

Option D. Insulinoma: Is an Insulin secreting tumours characterized by constant high production of insulin (C-peptide) and decreased blood glucose by the tumour cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by a set of symptoms that include flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm, and, in some cases, heart valve lesions. These symptoms are caused by the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors, most commonly originating in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs. Elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA), a metabolite of serotonin, in the urine or blood are a hallmark finding in carcinoid syndrome and support this diagnosis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: pg 557, DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 241-242

questions.text: Which of the following can be homologous substitution for isoleucine in a protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valine

 

Option C:

 

Valine is a homologous substitution for isoleucine because they are both branched-chain, nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acids of similar size. This substitution is likely to have the least impact on the protein's structure and function compared to the other options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Methionine - Although methionine is also nonpolar and relatively hydrophobic, it has a different side chain that includes a sulfur atom, which can affect the protein differently than valine or isoleucine.

 

Option B: Aspartic acid - This amino acid is polar and carries a negative charge at physiological pH, making it a non-homologous substitution for the nonpolar isoleucine.

 

Option D: Arginine - Arginine is a positively charged amino acid at physiological pH and is much larger, making it a non-homologous substitution for isoleucine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conservative (Homologous) Substitution:

 

  • One amino acid replaced by another amino acid of similar characteristics
  • Examples of homologous substitution is shown in the diagram given below.B

 

 

Nonconservative (Nonhomologous) Substitution:

 

  • One amino acid replaced by another amino acid of different characteristics

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 390.

questions.text: A researcher is utilizing different analytical techniques to study protein structures. Each method has a specific utility in the determination of primary, secondary, tertiary, or quaternary structures of proteins. Among the listed techniques, which one does NOT directly determine the structure of proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High performance liquid chromatography

 

Option A:

 

High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is a technique primarily used for separating and identifying components in a mixture, analyzing compound purity, or identifying concentration. It does not directly provide information on the structure of proteins at the level of detail that the other mentioned techniques do.

 

Note - The proteins are extracted and purified by various chromatography techniques such as ion exchange, adsorption, partition, size exclusion, affinity, HPLC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mass spectrometry can determine the primary structure (sequence of amino acids) of proteins and post-translational modifications.

 

Option C: X-ray crystallography is used to determine the three-dimensional structure of a protein at atomic resolution.

 

Option D: NMR spectrometry can provide detailed information about the structure and dynamics of proteins, particularly in solution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods for Separating and Purifying Biomolecules

 

  • Salt fractionation (e.g., precipitation of proteins with ammonium sulfate)
  • Chromatography: Paper, ion exchange, affinity, thin-layer, gas-liquid, high-pressure liquid, gel filtration
  • Electrophoresis: Paper, high-voltage, agarose, cellulose acetate, starch gel, polyacrylamide gel, SDS-polyacrylamide gel
  • Ultracentrifugation

 

Methods for Determining Biomolecular Structures

 

  • Elemental analysis
  • UV, visible, infrared, and NMR spectroscopy
  • Use of acid or alkaline hydrolysis to degrade the biomolecule understudy into its basic constituents
  • Use of a battery of enzymes of known specificity to degrade the biomolecule under study (e.g., proteases, nucleases, glycosidases)
  • Mass spectrometry
  • Specific sequencing methods (e.g., for proteins and nucleic acids)
  • X-ray crystallography

 

Ref: Harper 29/e: p 2, Vasudevan 9/e: p 45.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a newborn for potential metabolic disorders due to some concerning symptoms. Given the suspicion of phenylketonuria (PKU) among other metabolic conditions, the pediatrician considers the most effective screening method to identify such diseases in their early stages. Which screening test is considered the gold standard for detecting PKU and similar metabolic disorders in newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tandem Mass spectrometry  

 

Option D:

                                                       

  • Blood is obtained by heel-stick → applied to a filter-paper with four to six circles approximately 1 cm in diameter à allowed to dry and sent to a screening laboratory for further analysis.
  • Small circles of blood-soaked filter paper are punched out and metabolites are extracted with organic solvents.
  • Gold standard screening test for metabolic diseases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Western blot: Incorrect, as it's primarily used for protein analysis and not typically for newborn metabolic screening.

 

Option B. Electrophoresis: Incorrect, while it can separate molecules based on size and charge, it's not as comprehensive or specific for metabolic disorders as tandem mass spectrometry.

 

Option C. FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization): Incorrect, as FISH is mainly used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities and gene mapping, not for screening metabolic disorders like PKU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry (MS/MS) is widely used in newborn screening programs for the detection of various metabolic disorders, including phenylketonuria (PKU). This method allows for the simultaneous screening of multiple disorders by analyzing patterns of specific metabolites in a small blood sample, usually obtained via heel prick in newborns. Its sensitivity and specificity make it an ideal choice for early detection.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e :p 427

questions.text: A patient presents with an abnormal ocular finding as shown in the image. Considering nutritional deficiencies, which vitamin is most likely deficient in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Option A:

 

The given condition is called “BITOT’s SPOT”.

 

EYE MANIFESTATIONS OF VITAMIN A DEFICIENCY:

 

  • Night Blindness or Nyctalopia - The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light.
  • Xerophthalmia - conjunctival and corneal dryness
  • Bitot’s Spots - greyish-white triangular plaques adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • All the above-mentioned ocular changes are completely reversible with vitamin A supplementation.
  • Keratomalacia-softening of the cornea → Bacterial infection → corneal ulceration, perforation → total blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 deficiency → simultaneous folate deficiency due to the folate trap. C/F- all the manifestations of folate deficiency – reduced DNA synthesis, macrocytic anemia, hyperhomocysteinemia, Birth Defects and Cancer.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2: Manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth), Circumcorneal vascularization ,Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Includes Scurvy, Delayed Wound healing, Hemorrhagic tendency, and Weak bones. No eye manifestations are seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

Bitot's spots is a clinical sign of Vitamin A (Retinol) deficiency and understand the importance of this vitamin for ocular health. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to xerophthalmia and blindness if not treated.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 558-559, Lippincott 7/e : P 375-377

questions.text: The image below is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Windshield glass injury

 

The image displays multiple superficial lacerations on the face, which are typically caused by shattered windshield glass during a motor vehicle accident. These injuries, often referred to as "sparrow feet" marks, result from the fine glass fragments cutting the skin. This kind of injury is most commonly seen in drivers and front-seat passengers, as they are more likely to come in contact with the windshield during a crash. The back seat passengers are usually less affected because they are farther from the windshield, and not as many glass fragments reach them.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gunshot injuries: Gunshot wounds have distinct entry and exit wounds and are typically deeper, not causing superficial lacerations like those seen in the image.

 

Option B. Stab injury of face: Stab wounds tend to be deeper and more localized, unlike the multiple, superficial cuts seen in this case.

 

Option C. Vitriolage: Vitriolage refers to acid attacks, which cause deep chemical burns, not the kind of superficial lacerations seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Windshield glass injuries commonly occur in car accidents and present as multiple superficial lacerations, also known as "sparrow feet" marks. These injuries are most often seen in drivers and front-seat passengers due to their proximity to the windshield.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease (CAD), currently undergoing treatment, is advised to implement lifestyle modifications and monitor his lipid profile quarterly. Among the lipoproteins evaluated, which one is characterized by the lowest lipid-to-protein ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HDL

 

Option C:

 

High-density lipoprotein (HDL) is known for having the highest protein content relative to its lipid content among the various lipoproteins, resulting in the lowest lipid-to-protein ratio. This high protein content contributes to HDL's denser nature compared to other lipoproteins and its role in reverse cholesterol transport, where it facilitates the removal of excess cholesterol from cells and atheromatous plaques in the arteries, transporting it back to the liver for excretion or recycling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Chylomicrons: These are the largest lipoproteins with the highest lipid content, primarily triglycerides, thus having a high lipid-to-protein ratio.

 

Option B: VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein): VLDL particles are rich in triglycerides and have a higher lipid-to-protein ratio compared to HDL but lower than chylomicrons.

 

Option D: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein): LDL carries mostly cholesterol and has a lower lipid-to-protein ratio than VLDL and chylomicrons but higher than HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Among different HDL particles, percentage of lipids seen will be:  

 

HDL1 : 65%

 

HDL2  : 67%

 

HDL3  : 43%

 

Preβ-HDL : 30

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 478-479, 484.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes routine health screening, including a lipid profile, while fasting. Her results show a total cholesterol of 300 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol of 25 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 150 mg/dL. Utilizing the Friedewald equation to assess her cardiovascular risk, what is the LDL cholesterol level in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 245 mg/dl

 

Option A:

 

  • The total blood cholesterol in the fasting state is equal to the sum of the cholesterol in LDL + cholesterol in HDL + cholesterol in VLDLs.
  • This last term is calculated by dividing the triacylglycerol value by 5 because cholesterol accounts for about 1/5 of the volume of VLDL in fasted blood.
  • 300 = LDL cholesterol + 25+150/5
  • LDL cholesterol = 300-55= 245 mg/dl.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Friedewald equation, used to estimate the level of LDL cholesterol, is LDL = Total Cholesterol - HDL - (Triglycerides / 5).

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9/e: p241, 242, Lippincott 7/e: p 244
